title: Australians have until October 31 to lodge their tax return to avoid a maximum fine of $1,050
text:
Australians who fail to lodge a tax return in three weeks' time face being fined $1,050 - or even jailed.

Middle and average-income earners on salaries of $48,000 to $90,000 are entitled to $1,080 when they put in their tax return.

Those who miss the October 31 deadline face being hit with a maximum fine of $1,050, almost wiping out the tax refund they are entitled to.

Scroll down for video

Australians who fail to lodge a tax return in three weeks' time face being fined $1,050 - or even jailed (stock image of a woman receiving a document)

In the most severe cases, where somebody has failed to lodge a return for several years, the Australian Taxation Office can launch legal proceedings.

Should a tax evader be convicted in a courtroom, they face being fined up to $8,500 and jailed for up to a year.

Tax accountant H&R Block's director of tax communications Mark Chapman said the tax office had been known to seek the maximum punishment.

'They can prosecute you and that potentially will mean jail time,' he told Daily Mail Australia on Wednesday.

'That is extremely rare but it does happen occasionally, particularly where you have somebody who's got years and years of outstanding tax returns.'

An individual who lodges a return after October 31, or Halloween, faces being fined $210 or one penalty unit for every 28 days beyond that due date.

Middle and average-income earners on salaries of $48,000 to $90,000 are entitled to $1,080 when they put in their tax return

HOW MUCH ARE YOU GETTING BACK? Those earning $48,000 to $90,000 will see their tax cuts double from $530 to $1,080. Part-time workers earning less than $37,000 a year are getting a smaller tax cut of $255, or just $4.90 a week. Stage one increases the threshold for the 32.5 per cent personal income tax bracket from $87,000 to $90,000, over four years until 2022 Stage two, from July 1, 2022, will increase the 19 per cent personal income tax bracket from $41,000 to $45,000. It also raises the 32.5 per cent personal income tax bracket from $90,000 to $120,000 Stage three will see the 37 per cent tax bracket abolished from July 1, 2024 and a new 30 per cent tax bracket created for all individuals earning between $45,001 and $200,000. The number of tax brackets will be slashed from five to four for the first time since 1984

After several months, this adds up to a maximum of $1,050, or five penalty units.

Mr Chapman said someone who registered with a tax agent would avoid incurring that fine, and also have until May 2020 to lodge their return through an accountant.

'If they registered with a tax agent then nothing will happen,' he said.

'If you're a self lodger, and you've not lodged by the 31st of October, you're going to be late and you're looking at a late lodgement penalty.'

Since early July, more than 8.1million taxpayers have lodged a return.

That leaves another five million Australians who are yet to declare their expenses for the year.

'The balance of those people will be one who will lodge between now and the 31st of October, and there will also be tax agent clients who don't have to lodge until May next year,' Mr Chapman said.

In the April budget, Treasurer Josh Frybenberg unveiled $158billion worth of tax cuts for 10million Australian workers.

Those on salaries of $48,000 to $90,000 are entitled to the full $1,080 in tax relief.

Those earning between the tax-free threshold of $18,200 and $37,000 a year are receiving up to $255.

Tax relief is also going to those earning up to $126,000 a year.
description: Australians who fail to lodge their tax return by October 31 face being fined up to $1,050. Serial tax dodgers also face up to a year in jail - and a much stiffer $8,500 penalty.
authors: Stephen Johnson For Daily Mail Australia
